results.title: Fire of the land (A) [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: This beautifully written, produced and directed documentary by AFTRS student Valerie Bichard encapsulates the emotions and determination of a group of Aboriginal Australians seeking peace and justice in their campaign for Sovereign Rights. Isabell Coe of the Wiradjuri Nation in Central New South Wales, journeyed to the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra just prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games to collect ashes from the Sacred Fire in order to establish another Tent Embassy with these “healing” ashes in Victoria Park, Sydney. This is the story of Isabell’s peace campaign and the Tent Embassy in Sydney, the frustrations, negotiations, mediations and finally reconciliation with the South Sydney Council and the New South Wales Police. Through Isabell and other Aboriginal Australians including Kevin Buzzcott (Arabunna Nation Elder) and Chicka Dixon (Yuin Nation Elder) along with many of the Embassy supporters, an insight is given to the history of Aboriginal land rights, the birth of the Tent Embassy and the symbolic role which the Tent Embassy plays in promoting understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Also provides an appreciation and meaning of the importance of the Fire ceremony or “Healing” ceremony towards the act of reconciliation and how such ceremonies are part of Aboriginal culture and their spiritual attachment to the land.

Isabell Coe of the Wiradjuri Nation in Central New South Wales, journeyed to the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra just prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games to collect ashes from the Sacred Fire in order to establish another Tent Embassy with these “healing” ashes in Victoria Park, Sydney. This is the story of Isabell’s peace campaign and the Tent Embassy in Sydney, the frustrations, negotiations, mediations and finally reconciliation with the South Sydney Council and the New South Wales Police. Through Isabell and other Aboriginal Australians including Kevin Buzzcott (Arabunna Nation Elder) and Chicka Dixon (Yuin Nation Elder) along with many of the Embassy supporters, an insight is given to the history of Aboriginal land rights, the birth of the Tent Embassy and the symbolic role which the Tent Embassy plays in promoting understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Also provides an appreciation and meaning of the importance of the Fire ceremony or “Healing” ceremony towards the act of reconciliation and how such ceremonies are part of Aboriginal culture and their spiritual attachment to the land.

Isabell Coe of the Wiradjuri Nation in Central New South Wales, journeyed to the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra just prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games to collect ashes from the Sacred Fire in order to establish another Tent Embassy with these “healing” ashes in Victoria Park, Sydney. This is the story of Isabell’s peace campaign and the Tent Embassy in Sydney, the frustrations, negotiations, mediations and finally reconciliation with the South Sydney Council and the New South Wales Police. Through Isabell and other Aboriginal Australians including Kevin Buzzcott (Arabunna Nation Elder) and Chicka Dixon (Yuin Nation Elder) along with many of the Embassy supporters, an insight is given to the history of Aboriginal land rights, the birth of the Tent Embassy and the symbolic role which the Tent Embassy plays in promoting understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Also provides an appreciation and meaning of the importance of the Fire ceremony or “Healing” ceremony towards the act of reconciliation and how such ceremonies are part of Aboriginal culture and their spiritual attachment to the land.

results.title: Acquiring a taste for Raffaella
results.creator_credit: Sandra Lepore, Fotini Manikakis and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The onset of menstruation leads to a curious mix of events when Raffaella shares the news with her traditional Italian Aunt. Together they make some special Italian love biscuits, “biscotti di amore”, with a secret ingredient intimately linked with Raffaella’s menarche. When the object of her affections tastes the love biscuits, surprisingly, he asks for the recipe.

results.title: Shifting Sands: from sand to celluloid continued...(A)
results.brief_description: This video contains six short films about the lives of Aboriginal Australians living in today’s society. “Tears”, directed by Ivan Sen, is the story of a teenage couple as they walk from their northern mission station to a bus stop and await a new life with the girl’s father, who perhaps doesn’t know they are coming and who probably doesn’t care anyway. “My colour, your kind”, directed by Danielle McLean, is the journey through and to uncertainty of an albino Aboriginal girl who escapes from a severe Catholic mission to trek barefoot in a nightie across the outback. “Passing through”, directed by Mark Olive, a young family on their way to visit relatives pass through an old gold mining town. As the woman begins to delve into memories of her childhood, the family leave to continue their journey. Has she missed the opportunity to discover the secrets of the past? “Promise”, directed by Mitch Torres, is the tale of an old woman overseeing her grand-daughter making damper when she is asked how it came to be that she was betrothed at a young age. “My bed, your bed”, directed by Erica Glynn, in an isolated desert community, the time has come for two young people promised to each other under traditional law to move in together. Things don’t run as smoothly as they might. “Grace”, directed by Wesley Enoch, Grace is a middle-aged woman, living a comfortable life but when she returns to the mission where she grew up for the funeral of her sister she is confronted by the family she never met.
results.title_for_label: Shifting Sands: from sand to celluloid continued…(A)

results.title: Fire of the Land
results.creator_credit: Valerie Bichard, Eliza Johnson and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympics, ashes from a sacred aboriginal fire were taken to Victoria Park Sydney establishing the Aboriginal Tent Embassy, peace camp. Fire of the Land is the story of the Embassy’s campaign to get international recognition for Aboriginal sovereignty, capturing an unique moment in Aboriginal Protest history.
results.description: Prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympics, ashes from a sacred aboriginal fire were taken to Victoria Park Sydney establishing the Aboriginal Tent Embassy, peace camp. Fire of the Land is the story of the Embassy’s campaign to get international recognition for Aboriginal sovereignty, capturing an unique moment in Aboriginal Protest history.
description_for_label: Prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympics, ashes from a sacred aboriginal fire were taken to Victoria Park Sydney establishing the Aboriginal Tent Embassy, peace camp. Fire of the Land is the story of the Embassy’s campaign to get international recognition for Aboriginal sovereignty, capturing an unique moment in Aboriginal Protest history.

results.title: Eden
results.brief_description:
The Aboriginal relationship with the land in Australia is the original human relationship. The European conquest continues, with little change, in the destruction of NSW’s south east forests to this day.
Commentary by Benjamin Cruse (Eden Lands Council).
results.description:

results.title: Glass
results.creator_credit: Jacqui North, Safina Uberoi and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
He is an obessive bookmaker. She is addicted to talk-back radio. A film about love, loneliness and the dark magic of dreams.
Cast: Odile Le Clezio, Lech Mackiewicz, Dean Vassallo

results.title: Goblin market
results.creator_credit: Megan Harding, Belinda Hall, Rachel Perkins and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
“Morning and evening
maids heard the goblin cry,
come buy our orchid fruits
come buy, come buy”
Goblin market by Christina Rossetti
Adapted from the poem by Christina Rosette about an age-old myth as seen through contemporary Australian eyes.
Cast: Rachel Maza (Laura), Lisa Maza (Lizzie)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Megan Harding, Belinda Hall, Rachel Perkins and AFTRS

come buy our orchid fruits
come buy, come buy”
Goblin market by Christina Rossetti
Adapted from the poem by Christina Rosette about an age-old myth as seen through contemporary Australian eyes.
Cast: Rachel Maza (Laura), Lisa Maza (Lizzie)

results.title: Gods Bones
results.creator_credit: Catherine Sinclair, Samantha Lang and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Angie is pregnant but who is the father? Is it the taxi-driver, the businessman, the actor or the medical student? The potential fathers-to-be are all in for an unexpected mail delivery - a letter with an unusual little parcel. A reminder of what could have been. Based on a short story by Yasunari Kawabata.
Cast: Olivia Pigeot, Brian Vriends, Bogdan Koga, Ritchie Singer, Kiri Paramore

results.title: True justice?
results.brief_description: Documentary containing sensitive material about the death, in 2004, of a young 17 year-old Aboriginal boy from Gamilaroi country (Walgett) known as TJ Hickey. Through interviews and news footage, the film attempts to establish the truth of what really happened to TJ whose “acccidental” death not only triggered a riot between the Redfern community and the police, but also conspiracy theories, rumours and media misinformation.
results.description: Documentary containing sensitive material about the death, in 2004, of a young 17 year-old Aboriginal boy from Gamilaroi country (Walgett) known as TJ Hickey. results.title: Fuse
results.creator_credit: Marcus Waters, Katherine Shortland, Maia Horniak and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
A young Aboriginal girl wants to revenge the death of her older brother who has died while in jail for a petty crime. He was the only person she had in the world and now, desperately alone and angry, she finds the judge that sentenced her brother.
The film unfolds in the judge’s bachelor apartment where he is tied up and held captive as each of them confront their own judgements and their own pain.
An intense drama between two completely different people in one room over one night unfolds as they both behave in unexpected ways. Human emotions cross between the race, sex and class divide as each rediscover the meaning of loneliness, loss and judgement.
Cast: Shai Pittman, Chris Haywood
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marcus Waters, Katherine Shortland, Maia Horniak and AFTRS
